"if it "cannot" change, then I guess the people involved don't think it very
important to test it."

Thanks for the words. I hope you don't mind if I use almost the same exact
words in some other similar situations.

Start of pontification

This is a generic issue. I have had similar conversations while reviewing
Oracle PL/SQL code. They went "private happy". The standard conversation has
the format

Me: What would be the down side of making ... public ?

Reply: Someone might use it.

Me: Why would this be bad ? If the ... is properly documented there would be
no issues.

Reply: This means that I would have to write more documentation.

Me: That is a decision you have to make. Extra doco allows for more explicit
testing. Is it worth it ? Only you can make that decision.

End of pontification

  Kamal Ahmed wrote:

  > Since this is an API, The contracts and design cannot change to suite
junit,
  > hence I cannot change the visibility

  I hear this a lot. My attitude has always been the same: if it "cannot"
  change, then I guess the people involved don't think it very important
  to test it.

  By the way, this is not a JUnit limitation. It's a Java limitation.
  Since the method is protected, a TestCase in the same /package/ would be
  able to invoke it directly. Again, this is not a JUnit limitation, it's
  the way Java works.

  One of the unavoidable facts of testing (any kind of testing) existing
  code is that much code is designed in a way that makes testing difficult
  or expensive. If you want to test it effectively, it will have to start
  changing.

  Elliotte Harold is the poster boy (and I mean that in a good way!) for
  having both a minimal API and well-tested code. I don't feel quite as
  strongly about having a minimal API, but then I don't publish libraries
  much, so I don't have external motivation to care as much about it. He
  has shown that you /can/ have both, but you probably can't get there
  without making some changes to existing APIs.

  So it's your choice: which do you value more? The API as it is now, or
  writing good tests? If you value the first one more, you'll have to
  settle for longer, more brittle, more expensive tests. That's a judgment
  only your team can make.
